definitions.definition: Past tense of will ; usually followed by a bare infinitive.

subdefinitions.definition: Used to form the " anterior future ", or "future in the past", indicating a futurity relative to a past time.
examples: On my first day at University, I met the woman who would become my wife.
Hi! I thought I 'd come over and introduce myself. My name’s Chema .

subdefinitions.definition: Used to , did repeatedly , habitually ; indicates an action that happened several times in the past (cannot describe continuous states, as in I used to live in London )
Was or were determined to; indicating someone's insistence upon doing something .
examples: I asked her to stay in with me, but she would go out.

subdefinitions.definition: Used with ellipsis of the infinitive verb, or postponement to a relative clause, in various senses .

definitions.definition: A modal verb, the subjunctive of will ; usually followed by a bare infinitive.

subdefinitions.definition: Used as the auxiliary of the simple conditional modality, indicating a state or action that is conditional on another .
examples: If I won the lottery, I would give half the money to charity.
I' d never do anything that went against my conscience.

subdefinitions.definition: Without explicit condition, or with loose or vague implied condition, indicating a hypothetical or imagined state or action.
examples: I would love to come and visit.
Look at that yummy cake! I would eat that all up!
Most other people would do it differently, helping anybody who was in trouble, whether they knew them or not.

subdefinitions.definition: Suggesting conditionality or potentiality in order to express a sense of politeness, tentativeness, indirectness, hesitancy, uncertainty, etc.
examples: I would ask you all to sit down.
I would imagine that they have already left.
I would say/think we would /might do better to catch the earlier flight.

subdefinitions.definition: Used to express what the speaker would do in another person's situation, as a means of giving a suggestion or recommendation.
Used to express the speaker's belief or assumption.
examples: He's very security-conscious, so he would have remembered to lock the door.
They would be arriving in London round about now.

subdefinitions.definition: Could naturally be expected to (given the situation, the tendencies of someone's character etc.).
examples: Sorry, officer, I would n't know anything about the crime, since I was nowhere near the scene.

subdefinitions.definition: Used interrogatively to express a polite request ; are (you) willing to …?
examples: Would you pass the salt, please?

subdefinitions.definition: Might wish (+ verb in past subjunctive); often used in the first person (with or without that ) in the sense of " if only " .

subdefinitions.label_groups: chiefly archaic , transitive or control verb

main_definition: Past tense of will ; usually followed by a bare infinitive.
secondary_definitions: A modal verb, the subjunctive of will ; usually followed by a bare infinitive.
